Nemecsek Ern≈ë, in the book, is depicted as a young boy of the "private" rank within a children's gang, centered around adventures at a place called "grund." He is portrayed as brave and sensitive, deeply caring about how his peers, especially Boka, a leader in the group, perceive him. Nemecsek fears being despised and considered a traitor, which significantly distresses him, especially when his name is written in the "black book" as a traitor, marking a great humiliation for him.

Throughout the story, Nemecsek strives to earn recognition and stand his ground within the gang, obediently fulfilling tasks assigned to him, even when they seem unjust or unfair towards him. For instance, he tearfully sharpens a pencil for others, showcasing his obedience.

Nemecsek's character embodies lessons on perseverance, courage, and honor. The narrative focuses on his development and how he deals with challenges and strives to maintain his honor through trials. His story highlights the importance of recognition, friendship, and loyalty in the world of childhood.
